text: Aha, okay that's what I thought. A closed market never becomes active for betting again. In case a market gets postponed, it gets closed and then a new market may open with a different market_id.

text: I bump from_record by one less than the returned count, and check the overlapping record is the same for that very reason. 99% of the time it is, but you do hit cases where something has cleared in between calls and you need to start over.

text: That is quite a big question <@U013MLED3V1> and depends exactly what you mean by a peak. It can have a very simple answer or a very complex one.

elements.text: That is quite a big question
and depends exactly what you mean by a peak. It can have a very simple answer or a very complex one.

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> I have just tried to implement zscore smoothed algorithm, and applying that for historical prices traded on selection or just last couple of points my app recorded. Have a look at screenshot, on the left side you have got my code and test chart, on the right side algorithm applied on betfair data. My question is what other devs here use? Or if there was anyone trying to use ML, or really simply naive algorithm, just to compare couple of last time traded prices and from std  to detect up or down signal when detecting peak or negative peak. I am looking for any feedback, experience others have got.

text: It is as simple or as hard as you want it to be. Can be as simple as X(t-1) < X(t) > X(t+1) or as complicated as applying wavelet transforms. All depends on your criteria and sensitivity for what you consider a peak. I've used rational function approximation to detect really sharp peaks before but that may be overkill. Really does depend on what you consider to be a peak?

elements.text: It is as simple or as hard as you want it to be. Can be as simple as X(t-1) < X(t) > X(t+1) or as complicated as applying wavelet transforms. All depends on your criteria and sensitivity for what you consider a peak. I've used rational function approximation to detect really sharp peaks before but that may be overkill. Really does depend on what you consider to be a peak?

text: If you are talking tennis in-play, that's guided by the score. Basically each point can look like a new market, depending on the current score (and who won the last point). There is no point analysing in-play tennis for a "peak" because it's like analysing 100 separate markets for 100 points

elements.text: If you are talking tennis in-play, that's guided by the score. Basically each point can look like a new market, depending on the current score (and who won the last point). There is no point analysing in-play tennis for a "peak" because it's like analysing 100 separate markets for 100 points

text: <@U013MLED3V1> - no general algorithm will work. Some prices are forced one way by the way money is put on the prices. In-play is influenced by scores. You can't come up with a good general solution when you are solving different problems

elements.text: - no general algorithm will work. Some prices are forced one way by the way money is put on the prices. In-play is influenced by scores. You can't come up with a good general solution when you are solving different problems

text:
Hopefully a quick two-parter regarding live orders  (Market --> Blotter --> Live Orders) and market/runner exposure. My goal here is to calculate exposure at the runner level so I can handle inventory at that level (ex. if I already have X exposure on a runner then don't buy/sell any more [I don't know where to get the X number])
1. Is an order only considered live if it has at least some unmatched size in the market?
2. Once an order has been completely filled is it then considered where can I access them? Do I need to use market.blotter.strategy_orders(strategy) and then parse it down to the runner / market level?

elements.text: Hopefully a quick two-parter regarding live orders  (Market --> Blotter --> Live Orders) and market/runner exposure. My goal here is to calculate exposure at the runner level so I can handle inventory at that level (ex. if I already have X exposure on a runner then don't buy/sell any more [I don't know where to get the X number])
Is an order only considered live if it has at least some unmatched size in the market?
Once an order has been completely filled is it then considered where can I access them? Do I need to use market.blotter.strategy_orders(strategy) and then parse it down to the runner / market level?
